DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Gain On Export News
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices were slightly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board, reflecting new export developments, but other grain and soybean futures were narrowly mixed in listless trading. The wheat market got a boost from the Agriculture Department's announcement late Tuesday that it had targeted the Soviet Union for sales of another 2 million metric tons of wheat at subsidized prices in addition to the 14,200 tons remaining under a previous allocation. A new wheat allocation to the Soviets has been expected since President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev met earlier this month. ``We knew it was coming; we didn't know when,'' said Susan Leighty, grain market analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. In other export news, the USDA announced sales of wheat to China, Turkey and Egypt, and Japan was rumored to have bought U.S. wheat overnight. Further support stemmed from Tuesday's USDA announcement that an additional 3.3 million acres of land had been taken out of agricultural production and put into a soil conservation program. Ms. Leighty said about 2 million of those acres were in wheat country. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent to 1\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.15{ a bushel; corn futures were \ cent lower to } cent higher with March at $2.38{ a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to \ cent higher with March at $1.53 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to 1\ cents higher with January at $5.78 a bushel. Cattle futures were mixed while pork futures were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork belly futures were down sharply amid speculation that Thursday's weekly USDA cold storage report would show a higher-than-normal net increase last month in supplies of frozen bellies. Live cattle futures were .02 cent to .15 cent lower with December at 78.90 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .20 cent higher with January at 84.52 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .50 cent lower with December at 53.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .80 cent to 1.25 cent lower with February at 50.35 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed on Tuesday.
